perturbation.original_text: (x) "Know-How" means trade secrets, and other confidential and proprietary information, inventions, processes, formulas and methodologies.
perturbation.changed_text: (x) "Know-How" means generally known information, public knowledge, common knowledge, inventions, processes, formulas and methodologies.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Know-How" specifically includes "trade secrets, and other confidential and proprietary information." This change redefines it to include "generally known information, public knowledge, common knowledge" which directly contradicts the legal understanding of trade secrets and confidential information. The addition of those terms to the list makes the enforcement of the Know-How license uncertain. Trade secrets are defined under state and federal law as information that is kept secret and provides a competitive advantage. Including publicly available information negates the protected status of trade secrets.

perturbation.original_text: Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Arizona hereby grants to the Company a perpetual, non- exclusive, royalty-free license in, to and under the Arizona Licensed Copyrights for use in the Company Field throughout the world.
perturbation.changed_text: Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Arizona hereby grants to the Company a temporary, exclusive, royalty-based license in, to and under the Arizona Licensed Copyrights for use in the Company Field throughout the world.
perturbation.explanation: The change from a "perpetual, non-exclusive, royalty-free license" to a "temporary, exclusive, royalty-based license" introduces legal contradiction. Copyright licenses have well-defined characteristics under copyright law. 'Perpetual' means forever, and 'temporary' means of a limited duration, creating uncertainty about the duration of the license. 'Non-exclusive' allows the licensor to grant similar licenses to others, while 'exclusive' prevents it, contradicting the fundamental nature of the original license. 'Royalty-free' means no payment is required, whereas 'royalty-based' mandates payment. The modification will create uncertainty in the understanding of the contract.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party (the "Indemnifying Party") agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the other Party and its Affiliates and their respective employees, directors, officers, agents and successors (collectively, the "Indemnified Parties") from and against any and all losses (including all costs, liabilities (including present and future damages), claims and expenses) incurred or suffered by any of the Indemnified Parties, to the extent arising out of, relating to or resulting from (a) a breach by the Indemnifying Party of this Agreement; or (b) any gross negligence or willful misconduct of the Indemnifying Party in connection with this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party (the "Indemnifying Party") agrees to maybe indemnify, but not defend or hold harmless the other Party and its Affiliates and their respective employees, directors, officers, agents and successors (collectively, the "Indemnified Parties") from and against any and all specified losses, excluding all costs, liabilities (excluding present and future damages), claims and expenses incurred or suffered by any of the Indemnified Parties, to the extent arising out of, relating to or resulting from (a) a reasonable action by the Indemnifying Party of this Agreement; or (b) any ordinary negligence or accidental misconduct of the Indemnifying Party in connection with this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts the standard legal understanding of indemnification. 'Indemnify, defend, and hold harmless' is a standard clause that creates a clear obligation. By changing 'agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless' to 'agrees to maybe indemnify, but not defend or hold harmless' makes the obligation optional and uncertain. The exclusion of costs, liabilities, claims, and expenses severely limits the scope of indemnification. Furthermore, indemnifying for 'reasonable action' or 'ordinary negligence' contradicts legal norms, as indemnification typically covers wrongful acts, not reasonable or accidental ones.
